repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Andean Region Conservation and
            Sustainable Use of Biodiversity Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Andean Region
            Conservation and Sustainable Use of Biodiversity Project for
            Colombia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: balancing participatory
            approaches and the need for focused objectives - the open
            participatory approach adopted for project preparation
            ensured support for its subsequent execution but also
            pressed for ample objectives to encompass wide ranging
            interests. As seen earlier, focusing objectives is crucial
            to increase effectiveness and sustainability of project
            outcomes but implies ruling topics out. Balancing the two
            requires building stakeholder understanding of the issue, so
            as to adequately channel expectations into focused
            agreements. Seeking to adapt a national biodiversity policy
            framework to a six year project geographically too ambitious
            undermines achievement of outcomes. Co-coordinated donor
            investments and actions, in particular under a programmatic
            approach, should be actively sought to help strengthen the
            impact of single interventions. Results-framework and
            M&E schemes critically affect output-outcome and
            component linkages few and synthetic indicators focusing on
            how outputs lead up to desired outcomes help overcome
            segmented approaches to project implementation. As a first
            generation GEF project seeking to promote public and private
            conservation and sustainable use efforts in the Colombian
            Andes, including mainstreaming biodiversity considerations
            in sectoral practices and policies, the design of a useful
            M&E framework proved to be a challenge that was not surmounted.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Andean Region Conservation and
            Sustainable Use of Biodiversity Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Andean Region Conservation and
            Sustainable Use of Biodiversity Project, will increase the
            knowledge of biodiversity uses in the Andes region, while
            Colombia's National Biodiversity Policy, and proposed
            Action Plan, prepared within the framework of the Convention
            on Biological Diversity, will be launched. The components
            will: 1) Consolidate, and promote Colombia's National
            Protected Areas System in the region, and, provide support
            in testing elements in key protected areas. Investments will
            strengthen existing protected areas, and, a participatory
            design, and implementation of conservation zones will
            contribute to build relationships among local communities,
            and traditional managers of protected areas, through
            workshops, training, and technical studies to improve the
            quality of information. 2) Support assessments of
            conservation opportunities in transformed landscapes,
            develop, and disseminate management tools for biodiversity
            conservation in rural areas, and develop institutional, and
            economic incentives. 3) Strengthen regional capacities
            through training efforts in taxonomy, for a unified
            biodiversity inventory collection. In addition, a
            decentralized biodiversity information system will be built.
            4) Provide intersectoral coordination to promote inclusion
            of biodiversity goals in sector development plans for the
            Andes, through workshops, and improved monitoring practices.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Conservation and Sustainable Use
            of Biodiversity in the Andes Region Project (GEF) -
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment reviews
            potential adversity resulting from the implementation of the
            Conservation and Sustainable Use of Biodiversity in the
            Andes Region Project, which included a review of the legal
            framework for, and a consultation process with indigenous
            peoples. Based on lessons learned, that scientific technical
            assistance needs to be based on the recognition, and respect
            of autonomous indigenous decisions, particularly as it
            concerns their traditional methods to conserve, and manage
            biodiversity, the need to ensure adequate, and transparent
            mechanisms for conflict resolution, is imminent. Mitigation
            plans suggest: 1) the development of a continuous process of
            information, training, and evaluation with the indigenous
            groups, farmers, and conservation/scientific groups, to
            protect territorial integrity, and initiate environmental
            education with the agricultural communities; 2) provision of
            training programs to communities, to raise awareness of the
            biological value within their territories, and of associated
            social pressures. Norms for the use of resources shall be
            discussed, and prepared between communities, and local
            authorities alike; 3) in coordination with indigenous
            experts, and scientists, identify the botanical species
            traditionally used for medicinal purposes, to ascertain
            universal medical uses, build logistical support, and
            process information; and, 4) development of knowledge
            exchange programs, as well as promotion of native
            traditional production systems, such as home gardens, to
            build medicinal centers of traditional knowledge to assist
            patients, and, promote marketing of medicinal plants.
